channel.title: Function Modulation(range:Integer):integer;
channel.description:
know i dont contribute much to srl or its members but this is too big to pass up.
Ok i was reading a news article about how computer launguages do not have true random funtions rather Psudo-Random funtions. I became interested in it and i made a simple script to test a random number and print the findings. Well i did and i ran it through a program that finds patterns in things and low and behold it found a pattern. That peaked my curiosity because i believe that jagex could use this to catch us because the longer a script runs (1 hour+) the better apparent the pattern becomes (no im not crazy!). Well i got to reading and Pascal uses a complex algorithm called the "Wichmann-Hill psudo-random number algorithm" this a pattern that is made to look random but is actually not random at all (especially on small numbers)...Well i did nothing about it for 2 weeks. Then i mentioned it to MadCow about it not being random and he became interested and asked me what solution did i have. I didnt have anything at the time but i do now. Here it is
[code]
Function Modulation(range:Integer):integer; Var A, B, E, F, Modulated:Integer; C, D:Extended; Modded:Boolean; Begin Result := 0; repeat A:=RanDom(Range) B:=RanDom(Range) C:=Sqrt(A)+(Random(Range)) D:=Sqrt(b)+(Random(Range)) E:=Random(Trunc(C)) F:=Random(Trunc(D)) If(not SameValue(E,F))then Begin If (E+F<=Range) then Modulated:=(E+F) Modded:=true End; until(Modded=True) Result := modulated; End; [/code]

item.title: Function Modulation(range:Integer):integer;
item.dc:creator: @m0u53m4t m0u53m4t
item.description:
@m0u53m4t wrote:

And besides, lag on the players side causes enough random delay to the server anway.

Read full topic

item.title: Function Modulation(range:Integer):integer;
item.dc:creator: @Boreas Boreas
item.description:
@Boreas wrote:

Ron:

lol presuming there was a pattern, do you know how hard a pattern of waits to such an extent would take? Let’s see, there are over 150,000 players playing all the time, it must take about… 10% of one of Jagex’s computers per person to figure a pattern. It would be like trying to crack 128 bit encryption.

Therefore pretty much any pseudo random generator will do, whatever floats your boat.

Ron:

And obviously a human wouldn’t be able to figure out a pattern. Pointing that out, is just… insulting.

Didn’t mean to insult, I only pointed it out because you (a human) said

Those numbers don't seem to have a pattern at all.

Read full topic

item.title: Function Modulation(range:Integer):integer;
item.dc:creator: @Pyro Pyro
item.description:
@Pyro wrote:

I know that scar isnt perfectly random. And that nothign really is. But may i ask what you used to test this theory? Well anyways i made my own thing to test this theory. Try it out.

[scar]
program New;

const
TimesToTry=100000;

var
Store:array of integer;
Procedure PickRandom;
var
i,RandomNum:integer;
begin
for i:=1 to TimesToTry do
begin
RandomNum:=random(10)
store[RandomNum]:=store[RandomNum]+1;
//writeln(inttostr(i))
end;
end;

Procedure ProcessResults;
var
MaxR,MinR,MinN,MaxN:integer;
AveR:extended;
i,Total:integer;
begin
MinR:=Timestotry+1
for i:=1 to 9 do
begin
if(MinR>store[i])then
begin
MinR:=store[i]
MinN:=I
end;
end;
for i:=1 to 9 do
begin
if(MaxR<store[i])then
begin
MaxR:=Store[i]
MaxN:=I
end;
end;
for i:=1 to 9 do
begin
Total:=Total+store[i]
end;
writeln(inttostr(Total))
AveR:=Total/TimesTotry;
writeln(‘The Number ‘+inttostr(MinN)+’ Turn Up The Least At ‘+inttostr(MinR))
writeln(‘The Number ‘+inttostr(MaxN)+’ Turn Up The Most At ‘+inttostr(MaxR))
writeln(‘0[’+inttostr(store[0])+’] , 1[’+inttostr(store[1])+’] , 2[’+inttostr(store[2])+’] , 3[’+inttostr(store[3])+’] , 4[’+inttostr(store[4])+’] , 5[’+inttostr(store[5])+’] , 6[’+inttostr(store[6])+’] , 7[’+inttostr(store[7])+’] , 8[’+inttostr(store[8])+’] , 9[’+inttostr(store[9])+’] ')
end;

begin
setarraylength(store,10)
PickRandom;
ProcessResults;
end.
[/scar]

Read full topic

item.title: Function Modulation(range:Integer):integer;
item.dc:creator: @deathbyvirus deathbyvirus
item.description:
@deathbyvirus wrote:

Why not just do this, is pretty crappy but it’d give u a good random number, and i can almost garantee there is a pattern in it somewhere, but the pattern would be repeated over millions of numbers, and very very unlikely to be detected, like i said its not good i just had a spure of the moment idea and jotted it down:

Program New;
Var
a,b,c,d,e,f,range,count:Integer;
Begin
repeat
repeat
Range:=167+random(156)
a:=0+random(524)
b:=0+random(371)
c:=0+random(291)
d:=a+b
e:=d+b-c
f:=e/2
Range:=f-random(174)
until(Range > 0)
count:=count+1
writeln(IntToStr(count) + ' ' + IntToStr(Range))
wait(0)
until(false)
End.

wouldn’t this work just as well?

Read full topic

item.title: Function Modulation(range:Integer):integer;
item.dc:creator: @1337_macro 1337_macro
item.description:
@1337_macro wrote:

Boreas:

It can’t. But it can get close enough. By enough I mean a pattern that is too hard to find (in our case too hard for jagex to find). How close to random it is (how hard the pattern is to find) changes with the formula used, which is why 1337 made a different formula.

wow if it were only this easy at the villu forums lol… ya thats exactly y i made this procedure

Read full topic

item.title: Function Modulation(range:Integer):integer;
item.dc:creator: @Weibs Weibs
item.description:
@Weibs wrote:

Ya I just ran that odd or even thing 100 times in a repeat loop for 1000 times and I scrolled through the results, and about the first 100 were all either 74.something even and 25.something odd, or 75.something even, and 24.something odd. I’m gonna start doing more tests like most common or something.

But that even/odd thing could be pretty important, say you have this line:

If Random(3)=1 Then DoThis;

Well about 3/4 of the time the returned number would be even, therefore making the chances of getting the 1 about a 50% chance instead of 67%.

Read full topic
